title: Due Diligence applied to prospective senior employees

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
This request relates to the recent concerns about Child Sexual Exploitation in Rotherham and Sheffield. Sonia Sharpe was the Director of Children's Services for much of the period of concern, followed by Joyce Thacker, her deputy, who took over the role when Sonia became Director at Sheffield City Council.
When Sonia left Sheffield, her deputy there, Jane Ludlam, took over her role. In view of the subsequent issues about Sonia and Joyce, and the replacement Jane, can you tell me the about the recruitment process that took place when Sonia Sharp andJane Ludlam were recruited as Executive Directors.
In each case I am asking for documents held by SCC.
1. Where was the post of Executive Director for Children's Service advertised for each time the posts eventually taken by Sonia Sharp and Jane Ludlam.
2. How many applicants were there for the post for Sonia Sharp and Jane Ludlam respectively
3. What did the interview process involve (assessment centre, presentation, interviews etc) in each case.
4. References provided by Jane Ludlam and Sonia Sharp, ( anonymised as necessary ) with SCC evidence showing how each were checked.
Yours faithfully,
stygian

Dear FOI,
16 June 2024
My request was placed with yourselves on 16 April 2024.
Thank you for your reply, in which you apologise for not complying with the legal requirement to provide the information required concerning association with child sex exploitation and due diligence applied to the appointment of a senior employee who was in place during some of the worst years of child abuses.
Requests for information on other matters related to abuse have been sent to current chief executive Kate Josephs over the past two years, every one of which has been ignored, consistent with requests sent to her predecessors.
The public message is, in my opinion, clear that the management of Sheffield City Council is not fit for purpose.
Also, with respect to Freedom of Information management generally, the indications are that the time is long overdue for the Information Commissioner to intervene and impose external commissioners.
With respect to this case, the responses of Sheffield City Council are consistent with those of Rotherham Council, South Yorkshire Police, the past and current police and crime commissioner, and past and current MPs, in that there is an ongoing cover-up of information relating to child sex exploitation where disclosure would expose past and current senior politicians and public servants to account.
Another consistency is that all these individuals and organisations are from the same political party.
It is sincerely hoped that the  ongoing cover-ups will cease, and that the tens of thousands of victims and survivors of child sex exploitation can access a pathway towards closure.
All information on this request can be seen at:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/d...
Yours sincerely,
stygian

Dear Stygian,
Thank you for your chasing email of 16 June 2024 regarding your request
for information relating to Due Diligence applied to prospective senior
employees, which we received on 16/04/2024. We sincerely apologise for the
delay in response but have had a busy few weeks.
1.       Where was the post of Executive Director for Children's Service
advertised for each time the posts eventually taken by Sonia Sharp and
Jane Ludlam.
The time which has elapsed since recruitment means no data is still held.
2.       How many applicants were there for the post for Sonia Sharp and
Jane Ludlam respectively
The time which has elapsed since recruitment means no data is still held.
3.       What did the interview process involve (assessment centre,
presentation, interviews etc) in each case.
The time which has elapsed since recruitment means no data is still held.
4. References provided by Jane Ludlam and Sonia Sharp, (anonymised as
necessary) with SCC evidence showing how each were checked.
It would not be possible to anonymise the references which we hold. The
content of the references will inevitably identify one or other person.
Section 40(2) exempts information in response to a request if it is
personal data belonging to an individual other than yourself and it
satisfies one of the conditions listed in the legislation. The condition
contained in section 40(3A)(a) applies, that disclosure would breach one
of the data protection principles. The principle is that “Personal data
shall be processed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner...” We do
not consider that disclosing this information to you, and consequently the
public, is necessary or justified to satisfy your information request and
the requirements of the FOIA. In the circumstances of this request there
is no strong legitimate interest that would override the prejudice to the
rights and freedoms of the data subjects. We have therefore taken the
decision that disclosing this information to you would be unlawful.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please pass this on to the person who conducts Freedom of Information reviews.
I am writing to request an internal review of Sheffield City Council's handling of my FOI request 'Due Diligence applied to prospective senior employees'.
Thank you for your recent reply.
In summary you are saying that SCC is unable to provide evidence that Sonia Sharp and Jane Ludlam were employed at the conclusion of an exercise into due diligence.
There remains an issue with question 4:
4. References provided by Jane Ludlam and Sonia Sharp, (anonymised as
necessary) with SCC evidence showing how each were checked.
You have used exemptions Section 40(2) and Section 40(3A)(a) to exempt disclosure.
With respect, I believe that, with redaction if absolutely necessary, these issues can be overcome.
Details of deceased persons can be disclosed.
Senior politicians and civil servants have no legitimate expectations of anonymity. so those exemptions can not apply, even if they are no longer 'in post'.
A full history of my FOI request and all correspondence is available on the Internet at this address:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/d...
Yours faithfully,
stygian

Dear FOI,
Thank you for your response to my request for review.
You have invited a reply if any points needed clarification.
You have written that the request and its review applies to the two named persons only.
This is not entirely correct.
However, when requesting the review, it was stated that deceased persons are not exempt.
In this context, this would apply to those persons, as yet unnamed, who may have been involved with the Due Diligence exercise.
You may wish to have another look at this issue in advance of any contact with the Information Commissioner.
You have written saying that you have assumed that I am satisfied with the responses to the first three questions.
This is not entirely correct.
This issue can be determined by the Information Commissioner.
In advance of this, you may wish to interrogate the data servers, as deleting the data from the various desktop or networked machines only deletes the links to the files, whilst the original data remains on the server, and also in the scheduled back-ups.
This exercise has proved useful in the past.
For your information, and to be helpful, when one of the two referenced people obtained employment abroad, there was a national scandal because the Due Diligence process turned out to be inappropriately carried out.
Their equivalent version of the Freedom of Information Act was engaged.
The principle that senior politicians and public servants have no right or expectation of anonymity still applies.
As far as can be seen, no attempt has been made to retrieve the correspondence with SCC and the organisation known as Common Purpose with respect to this request for information.
For example, but not limited to, references.
Again, for information, such information was provided by previous employers.
Before going to the Information Commissioner, and as part of this thread, before the engagement of SCC can be concluded for this request, would you please provide the metadata associated with this request.
Thank you.
Yours sincerely,
stygian

Dear FOI,
SCC:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/d...
Polite Reminder
On 16 April 2024 you were asked for information regarding personnel associated with information relating to Child Sex Exploitation and details of Due Diligence with respect to employees.
After confirming my identity on the same day you indicated that a response would be forthcoming by 15.05.24.
You were sent a reminder on 16.05.24.
On 16.06.24, still having not received the required information, you were sent another reminder.
On 22.07.24, you sent a partial reply along the lines of 'Information Not Held'.
Whilst I do not believe the whole of your answers, not least because of the connections with Child Sex Exploitation and ongoing cover-up, the request proceeded to Request for Review.
On 23.07.24 I made a formal Request for Review.
On 23.07.24 you acknowledged receipt of the Request for Review.
On 31.07.24 you sent your Review, assigned FOI 1102101 maintaining your position.
However, I maintain that the exemptions are invalid.
On 31.07.24 I provided you with points of clarification, which also highlighted procedural failings of SCC.
In that clarification I asked:
"Before going to the Information Commissioner, and as part of this thread, before the engagement of SCC can be concluded for this request, would you please provide the metadata associated with this request."
On 01.08.24 you acknowledged receipt.
It is now 26.09.24, and there is still not metadata provided.
Please be advised that this constant disregard for compliance with the FoIA now requires that this issue be formally raised with the Information Commissioner.
Please review your decision not to provide the request metadata.
Yours sincerely,
stygian
